title: Quotations and Quotation Marks
description: Master the proper use of quotations and quotation marks

questions.stem: When should text be enclosed in quotation marks?

options.label: For any text borrowed from another source
For direct quotations and specific titles
For emphasis instead of italics
For all proper nouns

questions.rationale: Quotation marks are used for direct quotations, titles of shorter works, and words used in special senses.

questions.text: She said that "the meeting was productive and that everyone participated well."
questions.rationale: This is indirect speech and shouldn't use quotation marks. Direct quote would be: She said, "The meeting was productive..."

questions.text: The prime minister stated, ______ the policy will be implemented next year.______
questions.hint: Is this a direct or indirect quotation?
questions.rationale: Direct quotations require quotation marks around the exact words spoken.

questions.stem: Where does the period go in this sentence: She said, "I'll be there at noon"

options.label: She said, "I'll be there at noon."
She said, "I'll be there at noon".
She said, "I'll be there at noon.";
She said, "I'll be there at noon;"

questions.rationale: In Canadian style, periods and commas go inside the closing quotation marks.

questions.stem: Match each punctuation mark with its correct placement:
questions.rationale: Periods and commas go inside; semicolons and colons go outside; question and exclamation marks depend on whether they're part of the quotation.

questions.stem: Arrange these punctuation examples from correct to incorrect:
questions.rationale: Standard comma placement is most correct, exclamation with comma is less preferred but acceptable.

questions.stem: When should a quotation be formatted as a block quote?

options.label: When it's more than 20 words
When it's more than 40 words or 4 lines
When it's from a famous person
When it contains multiple sentences

questions.rationale: Block quotations are used for longer quotations, typically more than 40 words or 4 typed lines.

questions.text: Long quotations are set off from the text by ______ and do ______ use quotation marks.
questions.rationale: Block quotations are indented and don't use quotation marks since the indentation shows it's a quotation.

questions.stem: How should quotes within quotes be marked?

options.label: Use double quotes for both levels
Use single quotes for the inner quotation
Use italics for the inner quotation
Use parentheses for the inner quotation

questions.rationale: Use single quotation marks for quotations within quotations.

questions.stem: Find the error in this nested quotation:
questions.text: The teacher said, "Remember the motto: "Knowledge is power" for tomorrow's test."
questions.rationale: The inner quotation should use single quotes: 'Knowledge is power'

questions.stem: Match each type of work with its correct formatting:
questions.rationale: Shorter works use quotation marks, longer/major works use italics.

questions.stem: Which sentence correctly formats the titles?

options.label: I read "The Great Gatsby" in "Time" magazine.
I read The Great Gatsby in "Time" magazine.
I read *The Great Gatsby* in *Time* magazine.
I read "The Great Gatsby" in *Time* magazine.

questions.rationale: Both the novel and magazine are major works that should be italicized.

questions.text: The poem ______ appears in the collection ______.
questions.hint: Consider the relative length and independence of each work.
questions.rationale: Individual poems use quotation marks, while poetry collections use italics.

questions.stem: When should quotation marks be used around single words?

options.label: For emphasis
For slang or words used ironically
For foreign words
For proper nouns

questions.rationale: Quotation marks can indicate irony, slang, or words used in non-standard ways, but shouldn't be overused.

questions.text: The "new" policy has been in effect for three years and provides "excellent" coverage.
questions.rationale: Don't use quotation marks for simple emphasis - they suggest irony or doubt.

questions.stem: Rank these uses of quotation marks from most to least appropriate:
questions.rationale: Technical terms and ironic usage are appropriate; emphasis and unnecessary quotes should be avoided.
